It immediately put us at ease (and the kids spent the next hour playing on the trampoline instead of helping out with unloading the car!) :)
The outhouse was a composting toilet - very clean, and a couple handfuls of sawdust on your "business" kept it smelling fresh. As for the wood-burning stove, it took us a little bit of time to learn how to use it, but once we did, it was very easy to maintain and keep the temperature straight. We slept very comfortably - they have a large, queen bed; a sofa sleeper; a lie-flat recliner; and plenty of floor space for sleeping bags/pallets/etc. Not to mention two very LARGE stuffed animals that were bigger than one of our kids!!
Kathy and the boys loved the various choices of cocoa, and once we got the kettle going on the stove, many cups were had by all. Their kitchen area has a microwave and a mini fridge, as well as all plates, utensils, napkins, etc. Any additional cooking items (pots, pans, etc) are not provided so you will need to bring your own, but Cami volunteered her Dutch oven to us and it was greatly appreciated! Also, there is a firepit outside if you want to do s'mores under the stars.
And, speaking of the stars... WOW! On a clear night, it is an absolute tapestry of God's majesty - you can see it clearly through the circular dome of the yurt's roof, but to get the full picture, you simply have to go outside. We got clear views of several planets, as well as the Milky Way, right outside our yurt. During the day, Lance let us know about a hiking trail that would take us to the top of one of the large hills in the area that used to be a ski resort run at one time. The view from the top is breathtaking - we would strongly recommend that hike to anyone!
Finally, the kids spent so much time on the trampoline that they were literally sore for the next few days. :) We would jump at the chance (see what I did there?) to stay here again. Thanks so much for opening your yurt to us, Cami and Lance! It was the experience of a lifetime.

We had a great time at the Yurt during our trip from Yellowstone to SLC. I was a little worried about the lack of air conditioning and limited water supplies in the midst of hot summer weather with two young children when I initially made the reservation. I was pleasantly surprised how much thoughts Cami and Lance put in the Yurt to overcome the challenges that come with trying to live in an isolated Yurt away from our normal industrial life. From bottled water to newspapers/matches to sawdust for the toilet, there is a solution in place for every concern I had before checking in. And don't worry, you still have electricity and cell signals. If you are visiting in a hot summer day with temp above 80F, I would recommend checking in a little late because it will be hot inside the Yurt no matter what you do but it cools down really quickly when the sun is no longer shining directly down through the ceiling. Overall, I would highly recommend it to anyone visiting or passing by Pocatello.
